text: Just saw a LinkedIn Influencer with 'Organic Growth' written in the profile with 65K+ followers claiming that he can help you in growing your platform, copying the posts from other influencers.

Jobseekers, this one’s for you.
 Every application, every interview, every follow-up… the pressure is immense.
 And I know what you're thinking: Am I not good enough? 
 But let me tell you, this isn’t about you or your skills. It’s about a broken system where 60% of applicants never hear back. 
 Your mental health is not worth sacrificing for a system that doesn’t acknowledge your worth. 
 Please remember, taking care of yourself is the real priority. 
 Your dream job will come, but for now, breathe. 🌻
Looking for jobs on LinkedIn is like online dating: Full of promises, but in the end, you’re just left ghosted.

LinkedIn scams be like: 'Congratulations, you've been selected for a role you didn’t even apply for!' 
 The catch? Pay Rs. 50,000 for the honor.

sapne dekhna achi baat hai,
lekin job ka sapna dekh ke 'interested' likhna,
yeh toh achi baat nahi hai na?

Next time when I'll be reading some LinkedIn Influencer's story, I am starting from the last line.
If there's a link attached to it, it's most probably a fake one.
Saves me time!

Every time I poured my heart into 5-6 rounds of interviews and faced rejection, it felt like a punch in the gut. The sleepless nights, the endless preparation, all for nothing.

But looking back, I realize it wasn’t nothing. It was the Universe’s way of saying, “Not this one, something better is on the way.”

Every single time, I’ve been shown why that rejection happened.

Doors I thought I wanted to walk through were shut, only to have the right ones swing open.

The kind that aligned with my growth, my values, and my happiness.

At first, it stung. It hurt deeply. But now, when things don’t go as planned, I don’t panic.

I don’t question my worth. I sit back, breathe, and trust. The Universe knows.

I know there's another plan waiting. Something bigger, better, and just for me.

To anyone feeling the weight of rejection: trust that the closed doors are protecting you from something you can’t see right now.

Your path is being cleared for something even more beautiful.

To everyone who's still looking for a job...

I see you. I feel you. 💔

Every rejection email feels like a punch in the gut, and every 'We'll get back to you' sounds more like 'You'll never hear from us.'

But I want you to know, you're not alone in this. 🌸

According to a study, 80% of jobseekers struggle with anxiety and self-doubt during their search. It's normal to feel lost, but it's not the end.

Take breaks, breathe, and remember, this doesn't define you. Your worth is not tied to an offer letter. 💥

Your mental health matters more than any job.

Sometimes, we forget that a company’s brand name doesn’t define someone’s talent. It’s easy to get caught up in the 'big company = big talent' mindset, but that's not always the case.

I’ve had the privilege of working with people from smaller companies (lesser known) who blow me away with their skills and dedication. They don’t need a fancy title or a famous brand behind them to prove their worth.

I've seen the other side too—people in top-tier companies feeling lost, overwhelmed, or stuck, even though the world sees them as 'successful'.

Let’s stop attaching someone’s value to the company they work for. Freshers especially need to hear this—skills are what matter, not the size of the company behind them.

At the end of the day, happiness and growth don’t come from a brand name, they come from doing what you love and constantly improving your craft.

I just said-

'Hope your son gets a manager like you.
I hope that the manager behaves the same way as you did with me.

Now tell me 1 thing-

She always said that she was a great manager.
Why will she get offended?

Hope you all become the people that your sons/daughters will like to work under 🙏

There are a lot of bad people/things, bring a small change and break the chain :)

I once failed 7 interviews in 2 weeks.
Each time, I thought it was over.
But in the 8th one, the recruiter said, 'We love your story and how you’ve grown.'
Sometimes, it’s not about proving you're the best—it’s about being the right fit.
Keep going.
The 'yes' you're waiting for could be one rejection away.

If you're a fresher reading this—stop obsessing over job titles.
A fancy title means nothing if the work drains your soul.
What matters is learning, growth, and being respected.
Choose that internship in a startup if it teaches you more than the MNC offer.

A friend got a job just by commenting thoughtfully on LinkedIn posts for a month.
No resume. No formal interview.
Just consistent, authentic engagement.
This platform works. Use it wisely.

Dear hiring managers,
Asking for 5 years of experience for an entry-level role isn’t visionary.
It’s delusional.
Let’s fix this broken system, one realistic JD at a time.

My first salary was ₹8,000/month.
People laughed.
Now, I lead a team that earns more than that daily.
Don’t let your starting point define your journey.
Where you begin is not where you’ll end.

Hiring someone just because they speak fluent English?
Let me remind you—skills are not language-dependent.
Great minds come with all kinds of accents.
Don’t filter out brilliance due to poor biases.

That awkward moment when the interviewer says:
‘We’ll get back to you soon.’
And then goes missing like your gym motivation after New Year.
At least ghost me with closure!

‘Let’s keep this professional’
– said the manager who expected me to work weekends, skipped appraisals, and guilt-tripped me for taking leaves.
Respect is the bare minimum.
Not a perk.

You are not lazy.
You’re exhausted.
Burnout isn’t solved by motivation—it’s solved by boundaries.
Log off. Breathe. Reclaim your time.
You’re allowed to rest.

PSA for all job seekers:
If someone asks you to pay for an interview—walk away.
Legit companies don’t charge you to hire you.
Stay sharp. Stay safe.
#JobScamAlert

LinkedIn is the only place where people get promoted from Intern to CEO in 6 months — according to their bios.

Meanwhile, I'm still waiting on HR to approve my email signature update.

Everyone talks about getting the job. No one talks about what it feels like when you get your first paycheck.

I cried. It wasn’t about the money. It was about the validation.

A reminder that you’re not just surviving — you’re building something. One step at a time.

Remote work isn't about being lazy. It's about being trusted.

If you need to monitor someone's screen every 10 minutes, you hired the wrong person or became the wrong manager.

Not everyone who posts here is showing off.
Some of us are sharing stories we wish someone told us when we were lost.

Support. Empathy. Realness.
That's why this platform matters.

A candidate once wrote ‘I’m willing to learn’ in bold in their resume.

I hired them.

Not because they knew everything. But because they were honest about not knowing and still willing to grow.

That hunger? Can’t be taught.

My boss once told me, 'Your job is not to work overtime, it's to create systems so no one has to.'

That stuck with me.

Leadership isn’t about who works the most — it's about who builds better.

Career advice no one gives you:

Be kind to your juniors.
They may be your future boss, client, or even co-founder.

Respect doesn’t follow hierarchy — it follows behavior.

Got rejected from my ‘dream job’ in 2021.
Felt like I lost everything.

Today, I work in a place where I feel valued, heard, and safe.

It wasn’t a ‘no’. It was a redirection.

Trust the detours. They know something you don’t.

If you’re a fresher and reading this:

You’re not ‘just a fresher’.
You’re a perspective they’ve never seen.
A spark they haven’t hired yet.

Confidence isn't arrogance — it's clarity.
Own it.

LinkedIn Tip:
Instead of writing 'Open to Work' only in your headline, try this:

✔️ Actively exploring data analyst roles | SQL • Power BI • Python | Ready to solve problems & tell stories with data.

Specificity stands out.

Make them see you before they meet you.

The resume got you the interview.
The conversation got you the job.
But the consistency is what keeps you there.

Career growth isn't just about big leaps. It's about the small steps you take every single day when no one's watching.

A mentor told me: 'There's a difference between being busy and being productive.'

Busy people talk about how many hours they worked.
Productive people talk about what they accomplished in those hours.

Work smarter, not just harder.

The most valuable skill in today's market isn't coding, design, or marketing.

It's adaptability.

Tools change. Platforms evolve. Industries transform.

The ones who thrive aren't those who master one thing – they're the ones who can learn anything.

To all the career changers:

You're not starting over.
You're starting with experience.

Every skill transfers. Every lesson matters.
Your unique path is your competitive advantage.

I asked 20 hiring managers what stands out in interviews.

Their unanimous answer? Candidates who ask thoughtful questions.

The interview isn't just about them evaluating you. It's about you evaluating them.

Curiosity signals confidence.

Failed three startup ideas before finding success.

Wasn't about luck. Was about learning.

Failure isn't the opposite of success.
It's part of it.

The average person spends 90,000 hours at work in their lifetime.

That's one-third of your life.

Stop treating your career like it's separate from your life.
It is your life.

Choose carefully. Choose intentionally.

No one talks about this, but company culture isn't in the free snacks or ping pong tables.

It's in how they respond when you make a mistake.
It's in how they react when you need a day off.
It's in how they treat the newest intern.

Actions speak louder than perks.

Rejected a higher salary for a better boss.

Best career decision I've ever made.

A good leader doesn't just develop your skills.
They develop your confidence.

And that pays dividends long after you leave.

Your network isn't about how many connections you have.

It's about how many people would reply to your message at 8pm on a Friday.

Quality over quantity. Always.

Imposter syndrome isn't proof that you don't belong.
It's proof that you care about doing good work.

Turn that self-doubt into self-development.
Let it make you better, not bitter.

Applied for a job I was '70% qualified' for.
Got it.

Later asked the hiring manager why.
She said: 'The other candidates knew how to do the job today. You showed the capacity to redefine it tomorrow.'

Hire for potential, not just experience.

5 years ago: Worked 80 hours/week. Burned out.
3 years ago: Worked 60 hours/week. Still burned out.
Now: Work 40 hours/week. Most productive I've ever been.

Productivity isn't measured in time spent.
It's measured in problems solved.

The most underrated career skill?

Patience.

Mastery takes time.
Recognition takes time.
Opportunity takes time.

We live in an instant society, but meaningful careers are still built one day at a time.

To anyone who feels stuck in their career:

You're not behind.
You're exactly where you need to be to learn what you need to know for where you're going next.

Trust the process. The dots connect backward.
